headline: Lululemon Stock Jumps on Strong Earnings, Improved Full-Year Outlook
summary: Lululemon reported third-quarter earnings that topped analysts’ expectations and raised its full-year outlook, sending shares sharply higher in extended trading Thursday.

headline: Lululemon (NASDAQ:LULU) Beats Q3 Sales Targets, Stock Jumps 10.3%
summary: Athletic apparel retailer Lululemon (NASDAQ:LULU) beat Wall Street’s revenue expectations in Q3 CY2024, with sales up 8.7% year on year to $2.40 billion. The company expects next quarter’s revenue to be around $3.49 billion, close to analysts’ estimates. Its GAAP profit of $2.87 per share was 5.5% above analysts’ consensus estimates.

headline: Lululemon (LULU) Q3 Earnings and Revenues Surpass Estimates
summary: Lululemon (LULU) delivered earnings and revenue surprises of 6.69% and 1.79%, respectively, for the quarter ended October 2024. Do the numbers hold clues to what lies ahead for the stock?

headline: Lululemon stock pops on earnings beat driven by sales outside US
summary: Lululemon (LULU) shares gain in extended hours after the apparel company reported quarterly results that beat Wall Street's estimates, with revenue at $2.4 billion — compared to $2.36 billion expected — while earnings per share (EPS) came in at $2.87, beating expectations for $2.75. Julie Hyman and Josh Lipton break down the earnings print, including a look at Lululemon's sales by region, on Market Domination Overtime. To watch more expert insights and analysis on the latest market action, check out more Market Domination Overtime here. This post was written by Naomi Buchanan.

headline: Lululemon: Fiscal Q3 Earnings Snapshot
summary: On a per-share basis, the Vancouver, British Columbia-based company said it had profit of $2.87. The results topped Wall Street expectations. The average estimate of 14 analysts surveyed by Zacks Investment Research was for earnings of $2.69 per share.

raw.headline: Lululemon: Fiscal Q3 Earnings Snapshot
raw.summary: On a per-share basis, the Vancouver, British Columbia-based company said it had profit of $2.87. The results topped Wall Street expectations. The average estimate of 14 analysts surveyed by Zacks Investment Research was for earnings of $2.69 per share.

headline: Lululemon raises annual forecasts betting on robust holiday sales
summary: (Reuters) -Lululemon Athletica increased its full-year forecasts on Thursday, betting on resilient demand for its athletic wear in the U.S. during the holiday shopping season and continued strength in its international business.  The company's shares rose about 8% in extended trading, with Lululemon approving an increase of $1 billion to its stock repurchase program.  Lululemon, like its peers, has had to keep its foot on the pedal when it comes to introducing fresh colors and prints to keep consumers engaged amid stiff competition from newer brands.

headline: Lululemon facing competition amid 'laser focused' consumers: Analyst
summary: It's a challenging landscape for some retail names, as inflation-weary consumers hunt for bargains. American Eagle Outfitters (AEO) shares tumbled after lowering its revenue estimates due to a weak holiday sales outlook.  Jane Hali & Associates Senior Research Analyst Jessica Ramirez tells Brad Smith and Madison Mills on the Morning Brief that "it hasn't necessarily been a very positive holiday season. What we're hearing, again, the consumer is… having a tough time and they are still strapped for cash. So everything that they are buying is with a laser focus mentality.” Shifting gears to Lululemon's (LULU) latest earnings print, Ramirez says that the athleisure company is facing tough competition for its consumer base. Ramirez points out there's "much more competition around Lulu. I think everyone has talked about Alo and Vuori, but there's also competition from upstart [running brands] like On (ONON) and Hoka (DECK) and even New Balance that have started tapping into apparel. And even though their apparel assortment is quite small at the moment, it is starting to resonate with some consumers.” While the company’s localized strategy has paid off with increasing China sales, in the US, “they had a slow down in the previous quarter and we do feel that might continue,” Ramirez says. To watch more expert insights and analysis on the latest market action, check out more Morning Brief here. This post was written by Kayla Hawkins.

headline: Court blocks Target’s attempt to move, dismiss DEI-related shareholder suit
summary: The lawsuit argued that Target’s “DEI/ESG mandates” had a “known risk of adverse customer reactions,” and should have therefore been disclosed in investor statements.
